content.text: **Intuitionist logic**, developed by L.E.J. Brouwer, rejects the law of excluded middle (A ∨ ¬A). For intuitionists, a proposition is only true if we have a constructive proof of it — existence claims require actual construction.

content.definition: A proof that doesn't just show something must exist, but actually constructs or exhibits it. Proving ∃x.P(x) requires providing a specific witness a and proving P(a).

content.text: Intuitionists reject proofs that assume ¬A, derive a contradiction, and conclude A — without ever constructing A directly. They require that existence be demonstrated, not merely shown to be non-impossible.

content.title: Classical vs Intuitionist
premises: Classical: To prove ∃x.P(x), show ¬∃x.P(x) leads to contradiction
Intuitionist: To prove ∃x.P(x), exhibit a specific x and prove P(x)
Classical accepts the first; intuitionist requires the second
content.note: Intuitionism demands we 'show our work' by constructing what we claim exists.

content.text: Surprisingly, intuitionist logic connects to computer science: a constructive proof of A → B is essentially a program that transforms evidence for A into evidence for B. The Curry-Howard correspondence formalizes this.

content.definition: The principle that for any proposition A, either A or ¬A is true. Classical logic accepts this; intuitionist logic does not — we can't assert A ∨ ¬A without knowing which.

content.question: What does intuitionist logic reject?
content.explanation: Intuitionists reject the law of excluded middle — we cannot assert 'A or not-A' for every proposition without a constructive proof of which one holds.
